org.chronos.chronograph.api.transaction

Interface ChronoGraphTransactionManager

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.AutoCloseable, org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.structure.Transaction
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ChronoGraphTransactionManagerImpl, ThreadedChronoGraphTransactionManager

    public interface ChronoGraphTransactionManager
extends org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.structure.Transaction
    A specialized version of the Apache Gremlin Transaction manager.

    Classes that implement this interface offer extended capabilities for transactions that work on temporal data stores.

    Clients can retrieve an instance of this interface via ChronoGraph.tx(). Classes that implement this interface must not be manually instantiated by clients.

    • Nested Class Summary

      • Nested classes/interfaces inherited from interface org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.structure.Transaction

    • Method Detail

      • open

        void open(long timestamp)
        Opens a new transaction on the master branch, at the given timestamp.

        Please note that only one transaction can be active on a thread at any given time. If a transaction is already open on this thread, this method will cause an IllegalStateException.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to read at. Must not be negative. Must not be larger than the timestamp of the last commit on the branch.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If there already exists an open transaction for this thread.

      • open

        void open(java.util.Date date)
        Opens a new transaction on the master branch, at the given date.

        Please note that only one transaction can be active on a thread at any given time. If a transaction is already open on this thread, this method will cause an IllegalStateException.

        Parameters:
        date - The date to read at. Must not be null. Must not be larger after the date of the last commit on the branch.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If there already exists an open transaction for this thread.

      • open

        void open(java.lang.String branch)
        Opens a new transaction on the given branch, reading the latest available version.

        Please note that only one transaction can be active on a thread at any given time. If a transaction is already open on this thread, this method will cause an IllegalStateException.

        Parameters:
        branch - The branch to open the transaction on. Must not be null. Must refer to an existing branch.
        Throws:
        org.chronos.chronodb.api.exceptions.ChronoDBBranchingException - Thrown if there is no branch with the given name.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If there already exists an open transaction for this thread.

          long timestamp)
        Opens a new transaction on the given branch, at the given timestamp.

        Please note that only one transaction can be active on a thread at any given time. If a transaction is already open on this thread, this method will cause an IllegalStateException.

        Parameters:
        branch - The branch to open the transaction on. Must not be null. Must refer to an existing branch.
        timestamp - The timestamp to read at. Must not be negative. Must not be larger than the timestamp of the last commit on the branch.
        Throws:
        org.chronos.chronodb.api.exceptions.ChronoDBBranchingException - Thrown if there is no branch with the given name.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If there already exists an open transaction for this thread.

      • open

        void open(java.lang.String branch,
          java.util.Date date)
        Opens a new transaction on the given branch, at the given date.

        Please note that only one transaction can be active on a thread at any given time. If a transaction is already open on this thread, this method will cause an IllegalStateException.

        Parameters:
        branch - The branch to open the transaction on. Must not be null. Must refer to an existing branch.
        date - The date to read at. Must not be null. Must not be larger after the date of the last commit on the branch.
        Throws:
        org.chronos.chronodb.api.exceptions.ChronoDBBranchingException - Thrown if there is no branch with the given name.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If there already exists an open transaction for this thread.

      • reset

        void reset()
        Resets the current transaction.

        By resetting the graph transaction, the transaction timestamp is updated to the latest available version. In other words, after calling reset(), all read operations will retrieve the latest available version. The transaction remains open after calling this method, i.e. clients must not call Transaction.open() after calling this method.

        The transaction will not switch branches during this operation. After calling this method, the working branch will still be the same as before.

        Please note that calling reset() will clear the transaction context, i.e. any uncommitted changes will be lost!

      • reset

        void reset(long timestamp)
        Resets the current transaction and jumps to the given timestamp.

        By resetting the graph transaction, the transaction timestamp is updated to the given one. In other words, after calling reset(), all read operations will retrieve the given version. The transaction remains open after calling this method, i.e. clients must not call Transaction.open() after calling this method.

        The transaction will not switch branches during this operation. After calling this method, the working branch will still be the same as before.

        Please note that calling reset() will clear the transaction context, i.e. any uncommitted changes will be lost!

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to jump to. Must not be negative. Must not be larger than the timestamp of the last commit to the branch.

      • reset

        void reset(java.util.Date date)
        Resets the current transaction and jumps to the given date.

        By resetting the graph transaction, the transaction date is updated to the given one. In other words, after calling reset(), all read operations will retrieve the given version. The transaction remains open after calling this method, i.e. clients must not call Transaction.open() after calling this method.

        The transaction will not switch branches during this operation. After calling this method, the working branch will still be the same as before.

        Please note that calling reset() will clear the transaction context, i.e. any uncommitted changes will be lost!

        Parameters:
        date - The date to jump to. Must not be null. Must not refer to a point in time after the latest commit to the branch.

      • reset

        void reset(java.lang.String branch,
           long timestamp)
        Resets the current transaction and jumps to the given timestamp on the given branch.

        By resetting the graph transaction, the transaction timestamp is updated to the given one. In other words, after calling reset(), all read operations will retrieve the given version. The transaction remains open after calling this method, i.e. clients must not call Transaction.open() after calling this method.

        Please note that calling reset() will clear the transaction context, i.e. any uncommitted changes will be lost!

        Parameters:
        branch - The branch to jump to. Must not be null. Must refer to an existing branch. If the branch does not exist, this method throws a ChronoDBBranchingException and does not modify the transaction state.
        timestamp - The timestamp to jump to. Must not be negative. Must not be larger than the timestamp of the last commit to the target branch.
        Throws:
        org.chronos.chronodb.api.exceptions.ChronoDBBranchingException - Thrown if the given branch does not exist.

      • reset

        void reset(java.lang.String branch,
           java.util.Date date)
        Resets the current transaction and jumps to the given date on the given branch.

        By resetting the graph transaction, the transaction date is updated to the given one. In other words, after calling reset(), all read operations will retrieve the given version. The transaction remains open after calling this method, i.e. clients must not call Transaction.open() after calling this method.

        Please note that calling reset() will clear the transaction context, i.e. any uncommitted changes will be lost!

        Parameters:
        branch - The branch to jump to. Must not be null. Must refer to an existing branch. If the branch does not exist, this method throws a ChronoDBBranchingException and does not modify the transaction state.
        date - The date to jump to. Must not be null. Must not refer to a point in time after the latest commit to the branch.
        Throws:
        org.chronos.chronodb.api.exceptions.ChronoDBBranchingException - Thrown if the given branch does not exist.

      • createThreadedTx

        ChronoGraph createThreadedTx()
        Creates a child graph instance that acts as a transaction.

        Multiple threads may collaborate on the returned graph instance, sharing the produced graph elements. When the first commit() or rollback() is invoked, the resulting graph transaction will be closed. Any element generated from that graph will no longer be accessible afterwards. The transaction is also closed when Transaction.close() is invoked on the graph.

        !!! IMPORTANT !!!
        WARNING: Even though the graph can be shared across multiple threads (in contrast to regular thread-bound transactions), neither the graph itself nor the elements are safe for concurrent access!

        Specified by:
        createThreadedTx in interface org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.structure.Transaction
        Returns:
        The child graph that acts as a thread-independent transaction. Never null.

      • createThreadedTx

        ChronoGraph createThreadedTx(long timestamp)
        Creates a child graph instance that acts as a transaction on the given timestamp.

        Multiple threads may collaborate on the returned graph instance, sharing the produced graph elements. When the first commit() or rollback() is invoked, the resulting graph transaction will be closed. Any element generated from that graph will no longer be accessible afterwards. The transaction is also closed when Transaction.close() is invoked on the graph.

        !!! IMPORTANT !!!
        WARNING: Even though the graph can be shared across multiple threads (in contrast to regular thread-bound transactions), neither the graph itself nor the elements are safe for concurrent access!

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp on which to open the transaction. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        The child graph that acts as a thread-independent transaction. Never null.

      • createThreadedTx

        ChronoGraph createThreadedTx(java.util.Date date)
        Creates a child graph instance that acts as a transaction on the given date.

        Multiple threads may collaborate on the returned graph instance, sharing the produced graph elements. When the first commit() or rollback() is invoked, the resulting graph transaction will be closed. Any element generated from that graph will no longer be accessible afterwards. The transaction is also closed when Transaction.close() is invoked on the graph.

        !!! IMPORTANT !!!
        WARNING: Even though the graph can be shared across multiple threads (in contrast to regular thread-bound transactions), neither the graph itself nor the elements are safe for concurrent access!

        Parameters:
        date - The date on which to open the transaction. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The child graph that acts as a thread-independent transaction. Never null.

      • createThreadedTx

        ChronoGraph createThreadedTx(java.lang.String branchName)
        Creates a child graph instance that acts as a transaction on the given branch.

        Multiple threads may collaborate on the returned graph instance, sharing the produced graph elements. When the first commit() or rollback() is invoked, the resulting graph transaction will be closed. Any element generated from that graph will no longer be accessible afterwards. The transaction is also closed when Transaction.close() is invoked on the graph.

        !!! IMPORTANT !!!
        WARNING: Even though the graph can be shared across multiple threads (in contrast to regular thread-bound transactions), neither the graph itself nor the elements are safe for concurrent access!

        Parameters:
        branchName - The name of the branch on which to open the transaction. Must not be null. Must refer to an existing branch.
        Returns:
        The child graph that acts as a thread-independent transaction. Never null.

      • createThreadedTx

        ChronoGraph createThreadedTx(java.lang.String branchName,
                             long timestamp)
        Creates a child graph instance that acts as a transaction on the given branch and timestamp.

        Multiple threads may collaborate on the returned graph instance, sharing the produced graph elements. When the first commit() or rollback() is invoked, the resulting graph transaction will be closed. Any element generated from that graph will no longer be accessible afterwards. The transaction is also closed when Transaction.close() is invoked on the graph.

        !!! IMPORTANT !!!
        WARNING: Even though the graph can be shared across multiple threads (in contrast to regular thread-bound transactions), neither the graph itself nor the elements are safe for concurrent access!

        Parameters:
        branchName - The name of the branch on which to open the transaction. Must not be null. Must refer to an existing branch.
        timestamp - The timestamp on which to open the transaction. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        The child graph that acts as a thread-independent transaction. Never null.

      • createThreadedTx

        ChronoGraph createThreadedTx(java.lang.String branchName,
                             java.util.Date date)
        Creates a child graph instance that acts as a transaction on the given branch and date.

        Multiple threads may collaborate on the returned graph instance, sharing the produced graph elements. When the first commit() or rollback() is invoked, the resulting graph transaction will be closed. Any element generated from that graph will no longer be accessible afterwards. The transaction is also closed when Transaction.close() is invoked on the graph.

        !!! IMPORTANT !!!
        WARNING: Even though the graph can be shared across multiple threads (in contrast to regular thread-bound transactions), neither the graph itself nor the elements are safe for concurrent access!

        Parameters:
        branchName - The name of the branch on which to open the transaction. Must not be null. Must refer to an existing branch.
        date - The date on which to open the transaction. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The child graph that acts as a thread-independent transaction. Never null.

      • getCurrentTransaction

        ChronoGraphTransaction getCurrentTransaction()
        Returns the actual graph transaction that is serving the current thread.

        For internal purposes only.

        Returns:
        The transaction for the current thread, or null if there is no graph transaction bound to the current thread.
